div.div: Problem: Your editor doesn't automatically suggest properties.
Example: If you have const user = { name: "Maria", age: 30 }; and type user., JavaScript won't automatically suggest name or age.

Consequence: Typographical errors (e.g., user.naem) aren't caught until runtime, leading to undefined.const user = { name: "Maria", age: 30 }; console.log(user.naem); // Mistake! But you won't see it until you run the code!
Lack of Autocomplete / Intellisense:
Problem: JavaScript doesn't check the types of parameters in functions.
Absence of Parameter Checking:
Problem: Changing function or property names requires manual search and replacement across all files.
Example: If you have function calculateTotal(price, quantity) { return price * quantity; } used in 100+ files and you change it to computeTotal.
Risk: Forgotten changes lead to runtime errors. In TypeScript, it would show you all usage points and allow a safe rename with one click.
Difficulty Refactoring in Large Projects:
Limitations of JavaScript
Allowed writing typed code.
Provided compile-time checks (error checking during compilation).
Converted to JavaScript for browser use.
Microsoft "Script# (ScriptSharp)":
Early Efforts (around 2010):
Seeking a Solution
Syntax: Close to JavaScript.
Conversion: Ability to transpile (convert to JavaScript).
Tools: Built-in type checking and safety.
New Language from Microsoft:
Continued Development: Maintained by Microsoft for over 10 years.
The Birth of TypeScript
Error Detection: Shows errors as you write code (before execution).
Tool Support: Offers Intellisense and Autocomplete.
Safe Refactoring: Makes code refactoring easy and safe.
Function calls with incorrect parameter types.
Accessing non-existent properties.
Calling undefined functions.
Specific Error Detection: Finds errors such as:
Advantages of TypeScript vs. JavaScript
Using TypeScript elevates your development experience, making your code more robust and easier to maintain.
It's a step towards the next generation of development.
Conclusion
The Relationship Between TypeScript and JavaScript
